hints.content:
First, let's find the area and perimeter of the striped rectangle.  

[[☃ image 1]]

We can find area of a rectangle by multiplying its length by its width.  
Area $= \greenD{3} \times \greenD{4} \!=\!\! \greenD{12} \text{ sq cm}$ 

We find perimeter by adding the lengths of the sides.  
Perimeter $= \greenD3 + \greenD3 + \greenD{4} + \greenD{4} = \greenD{14} \text{ cm}$

options.alt: A wide rectangle. Along its left side, the rectangle is labeled 3 centimeters. Along the top, it is labeled 4 centimeters. !

hints.content:
Next, we find the area and perimeter of the other rectangle. 

$$ | Area | Perimeter
:- | :- | :-
![A wide rectangle. Along its left side, the rectangle is labeled 3 centimeters. Along the top, it is labeled 4 centimeters.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/7b2f3fa6e24d4ee5221bcd1659bb815241a9b5a1) | $ \greenD{3} \times \greenD{4} \!=\!\! \greenD{12} \text{ sq cm}$     | $ \greenD3 + \greenD3 + \greenD{4} + \greenD{4} = \greenD{14} \text{ cm}$ 
![A tall rectangle. Along its left side, the rectangle is labeled 4 centimeters. Along the top, it is labeled 3 centimeters.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/261551cebd6bc64e22c450fae9e5b352295f53d8)  | $\redD3 \times \redD4 = \redD{12} \text{ sq cm}$ | $\redD3 + \redD3 + \redD4 + \redD4 =\redD{14} \text{ cm}$

Now, lets compare the area and perimeters of the rectangles.

Area:  
$\greenD{12}\text { sq  cm}=\redD{12}\text{ sq cm}$

Perimeter:  
$\greenD{14}\text { cm}=\redD{14}\text{ cm}$
The rectangles have the same area and perimeter.
